Developers are speeding up final testing, the Chinese foreign minister said during a U.N. meeting last week    https://web.archive.org/web/20201207184213/https://www.politico.com/news/2020/12/06/china-prepares-large-scale-rollout-of-coronavirus-vaccines-443159

This extended note aims to capture the progress on vaccination programme before it is rolled out to the entire country (does not include R&D, clinic trials).    The China National Medicine Products Administration (MPA) has not formally approved the Sinopharm Inactivated vaccine to go to the market. However, the green light is anticipated in the next few days.     http://web.archive.org/web/20201214212000/https://weareunited.com.my/11515744/    On 24 June 2020, the MPA approved the emergency use of COVID-19 vaccine. Voluntary vaccination started on around 17 June. The first batch of receivers consisted mainly of key workers, including state-owned enterprise employees who must go overseas to countries where the pandemic hits hard; medical staff, epidemic-control staff, border force and other essential workers who keep cities running.     http://web.archive.org/web/20201214231804/https://finance.sina.com.cn/chanjing/cyxw/2020-11-18/doc-iiznezxs2537217.shtml    From mid-October, Zhejiang province has offered vaccines to ordinary citizens on a voluntary basis. The rationale has been that many cities in Zhejiang have export-oriented economies; for example, Yiwu city is the world centre for light industry commodity trading. Many wholesale merchants were keen on receiving vaccines so that they can travel to Latin America and Africa to inspect their businesses. See BBC reports below. By mid-November, Zhejiang had provided vaccines to some 743,000 people. Voluntary vaccines were paid by recipients. Two doses cost roughly 400 CNY plus a service charge of around 56 CNY, which altogether equals to approximately 70 USD.     http://web.archive.org/web/20201214231741/https://www.bbc.com/zhongwen/simp/chinese-news-54628714    As the vaccination programme is yet to roll out to the whole country, there is no national policy on who will get the vaccine first. However, Sichuan province, where the most recent cluster of infection was found, did publish a detailed plan to that sets out the order:    The first group to receive vaccines consists of people facing high risks of infection, including medical staffs with International assistance mission, national health emergency rescue team in Sichuan, fever clinic and frontline doctors and nurses, border control force, frontline health inspection and epidemic-control officials, students or workers going overseas, police force, frozen food industry workers, essential workers for keeping cities running, teachers, other medical staffs, doctors and nurses, community social workers. The first batch is estimated to have 2 million people. Vaccination for them has started and will finish within 2020.    The second group to receive vaccines mainly consists of vulnerable people, including elderly people and people with chronic diseases. Vaccination for them will start from early next year (January).    The third batch will open to the general public. Ordinary people are estimated to start receiving vaccines after the Chinese New Year (12 February 2021).    http://web.archive.org/web/20201214221555/https://www.sohu.com/a/437018675_114988    So far, vaccination is not and is unlike to be paid by social medical insurance funds in the future. The National Health Security Administration has cited laws and regulations as the justification that vaccination is a part of public health effort, which should be shouldered by public finance resources, rather than social medical insurance funds.     http://web.archive.org/web/20201214211226/https://www.sohu.com/a/425495553_114986    UAE and Bahrain have formally approved the Sinopharm vaccine on 9th and 13th December 2020 respectively.    http://web.archive.org/web/20201214231619/http://www.xinhuanet.com/2020-12/09/c_1126842251.htm  http://web.archive.org/web/20201214231549/http://www.xinhuanet.com/world/2020-12/14/c_1126855787.htm

Malaysia continues to adjust restrictions to stem the spread of coronavirus disease (COVID-19) as of Dec. 7. Authorities have lifted stricter protocols, termed the conditional movement control order (CMCO), in most states.     Nationwide restrictions under the recovery movement control order (RMCO), which is the least stringent set of protocols, remain in effect across most parts of Malaysia through Dec. 31.     States implementing RMCO include Malacca, Pahang, Perlis, Sarawak, and Terengganu. Educational institutions remain closed until further notice.    The CMCO or even the enhanced movement control order continues in Kuala Lumpur, Sabah State, and specific localities in other states, including six districts in Selangor State, as well as parts of Johor, Kelantan, Negeri Sembilan, Penang, and Perak, through Dec. 20. In these places, all educational institutions are suspended.    http://web.archive.org/web/20201221170524/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/409741/malaysia-covid-19-restrictions-adjusted-in-most-states-as-of-dec-7-update-18

For the more relaxed RMCO states, Most businesses can operate, though public places where social distancing controls are hard to enforce, like nightclubs, remain closed. Sporting events can occur, provided that organizers observe health guidelines. Food outlets and convenience stores can operate until 0200 nightly. Public transport can operate with protocols in place.    For the more stringent EMCO states, while measures may also vary by location, typical controls include the suspension of places of worship, and cultural, recreational, and sporting activities. Furthermore, the central government has designated areas recording more than 40 COVID-19 cases in the previous two weeks as red zones; such areas may see local restrictions. Central authorities may extend stricter curbs in some locations or expand the protocols to additional areas, depending on local COVID-19 activity.    Several state governments are maintaining additional statewide restrictions on top of those mandated by the central authorities. Some states may require businesses, such as hair salons and night markets, to remain closed. Additional curbs include limiting business operation hours, though exemptions are likely for essential services.  http://web.archive.org/web/20201221170524/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/409741/malaysia-covid-19-restrictions-adjusted-in-most-states-as-of-dec-7-update-18

Under all levels of all CMCO, Authorities continue to discourage mass gatherings. Violations are punishable by fines of up to MYR 1,000 (USD 240).    http://web.archive.org/web/20201221170524/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/409741/malaysia-covid-19-restrictions-adjusted-in-most-states-as-of-dec-7-update-18

Travel Restrictions most foreigners remain banned from entering Malaysia; exemptions are in place for resident diplomats, foreign spouses and dependents of Malaysian citizens, long-term pass holders, and expatriate employees working in essential industries and their dependents, among others.     Arriving expatriate employees must present an approval letter from authorities. Travelers must test for COVID-19 upon arrival. Those testing positive will undergo treatment at medical facilities, while those testing negative will quarantine for 14 days at designated locations.     Travelers must also download the MySejahtera contact tracing application. Foreigners may transit at Malaysian airports as long as they do not pass through immigration points.     Malaysian nationals remain banned from traveling abroad, with limited exceptions. Emergency repatriation of citizens may occur on a case-by-case basis.    Malaysia allows limited cross-border travel with Singapore for business and official purposes. Under the Reciprocal Green Lane (RGL) scheme, people can travel short-term from Singapore to Malaysia with an exemption from normal quarantine requirements for arrivals. The travelers must present approval letters from immigration authorities and a company or government agency in Malaysia, obtain visas if required, and test for COVID-19 within 72 hours before travel and upon arrival. Such travelers must comply with a controlled itinerary for the first 14 days and contact tracing measures. Additionally, in the Periodic Commuting Arrangement (PCA) scheme for long-term work visa holders, only people traveling to Johor State can quarantine at their residence or accommodations for seven days upon arrival, while those going to other Malaysian states must isolate at government-designated facilities for a week. Travelers can leave the quarantine sites upon testing negative for COVID-19. The PCA program allows the travelers to undertake multiple-entry visits through land border crossings at Woodlands or Tuas for 90-day stays once their applications are approved. Travelers are eligible for a home leave of two to four weeks after every minimum stay of 90 days in the country where they work.    http://web.archive.org/web/20201221170524/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/409741/malaysia-covid-19-restrictions-adjusted-in-most-states-as-of-dec-7-update-18
